title: What kind of assistance can a lawyer provide for a federal student loan debt crisis?
question: I owe $70,000 in federal student loans and with my current salary, even on an income driven repayment plan I am unable to make the monthly payments due to the high cost of living in California. I am an Registered Nurse with my Bachelors degree, which I received from Northern Arizona University. I am married and have one child. I am currently in a forbearance, but I am limited on how many months I can continue it. I made full and timely monthly payments on an income driven repayment plan for 5 years, but the payments did not cover the interest accruing, so my debt has continued to grow despite my payments. Now with my California salary my payments could be close to $800/month, which I can not afford. I was directed to Avvo for assistance through another law firm, that currently does not have assistance for federal loans. Please advise, any assistance or guidance would be greatly appreciated.
answers: Federal Bankruptcy is a complex area of law. More and more, across the country, some attorneys are focusing parts or all of their practices on student loan law. Engaging a College Debt attorney to help you navigate towards a student loan resolution is a good idea. College Debt attorneys can help you select a repayment plan, determine if you might qualify for loan forgiveness (for example, you mentioned you are a nurse - perhaps you qualify for Public Service Student Loan Forgiveness). I have written extensively on this subject here: CollegeDebtLaw.com

Bankruptcy relief for student loans is difficult to obtain. You basically have to show that you are in a situation in which you have to decide between food on the table and payment of the loan.

In bankruptcy, this is done via a trial before the bankruptcy judge. There is no jury. The result can be appealed to the Bankruptcy Appellate Panel, and then to the 9th Circuit.

As an alternative, most lenders are going to be subject to Fair Lending Laws, so an argument of lending discrimination (disparate treatment or disparate impact) can be made in federal court. Be aware that the courts and US Senate majority are trying to cut back on consumer protections, and these doctrines of law are virtually hanging by a thread, despite being on the books for decades.

Last alternatives are going directly to the Ofc of the Comptroller of the Currency, which oversees the activities of federal lenders, and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which some in the government are trying to destroy.

If you are not in default on your federal student loans, you should apply again for Income Based Repayment (IBR) aka Income Driven Repayment (IDR). The payment will be no more than 15 per cent of your "disposable income." The disposable income figure is determined by your gross income (as shown on tax returns), minus the federal poverty figure for your family size. The IBR payment should be much less than $800 a month. Don't let the loan servicer convince you that the FULL payment is the only payment you can make.

In many situations, the payment under IBR does not cover the interest that is accruing on the loan, but that should not stop you from enrolling. Yearly enrollment in IBR will keep you out of default, and will allow you to maintain a decent credit, have access to loans, housing, etc. After 20 years of enrollment in IBR, the amount still owed on the loans will be discharged.
Consider filing C13 BK and schedultin repatment ove period up to 5 years on best efforts basis.
